[S60] This is true even if the steps taken to apply life cycle thinking are small. [S61] ### Consumers

[S62] Due to several factors, the environmental impact of a product purchase may not be a deciding factor when it comes to choosing a product. [S63] Consumers may not be aware of the product's energy usage, questionable labor conditions that produced it, hazardous waste from production, impacts on the ecosystem, or pollution of air or water. [S64] Consumers can apply life cycle thinking in multiple different ways with regards to their product choices to reduce their impact on the environment. [S65] Many companies provide sustainability reports that consumers can read to educate themselves. [S66] By using life cycle thinking, consumers can choose a company with reduced environmental impacts. [S67] Primarily, consumer usage has the largest impact on the environment throughout a product's life. [S68] By using life cycle thinking this impact can be reduced. [S69] This would require educating consumers to make better choices about product usage. [S71] Consumer education starts with a self-assessment; for example, consumers can ask themselves what impacts they have while using the product and whether they can pursue more environmentally friendly alternatives. [S85] They do so by gathering information as a baseline of the environmental impact and using that to set goals based on knowledge from life cycle thinking. [S86] They can also use trends from the supply chains of different businesses they regulate to determine where the biggest influence can be made to majorly reduce the impacts of the businesses. [S87] Government sectors can also use life cycle thinking to better educate consumers. [S88] Requiring labels on products describing the impacts the product has and how to use the products to reduce the impact can be an important role for the government. [S89] Regulating supply chains and consumers with policy is motivational as negative reinforcement. [S90] Life cycle thinking provides a methodology for creating those policies to most effective and cost efficient means of reducing environmental impacts. [S91] ## In policy

Many consumers, when making decisions on what to buy and what not to buy, consider the environmental impact of the particular product. [S92] Policymakers recognize this desire and act to create policy that not only helps consumers do this but will do so while keeping a growing economy in mind. [S93] ### European policy

There are many aspects of life cycle thinking incorporated into European policy. [S94] The Sustainable Consumption and Production Action Plan is a piece of legislation that aims to reduce the environmental impact and consumption of resources associated with the complete life cycles of goods and services. [S95] On July 16, 2008, the European Commission presented this legislation. [S96] This proposal suggests plans on how to not only reduce the environmental impacts of goods and services but also encourage the use of more sustainable goods and production technologies. [S97] This action plan also encourages the European Union to seek out every opportunity to innovate in the industry. [S98] The Integrated Product Policy is another legislative action that Europe has taken to facilitate life cycle thinking. [S99] The Integrated Product Policy seeks to minimize the environmental degradation caused by the manufacturing, use, and disposal of all products. [S100] This legislation looks at all aspects of the product's life cycle and takes action where necessary to reduce. [S101] The Thematic Strategy on Sustainable Use of Natural Resources was implemented on 21 December 2005 to reduce environmental impacts associated with resource use and to do this in a growing economy. [S102] The objective can be described as "ensuring that the consumption of resources and their associated impacts do not exceed the carrying capacity of the environment and breaking linkages between economic growth and resource use". [S104] There are Environmental Product Declarations that are used to incorporate life cycle thinking into companies and organizations. [S105] They communicate to the consumer the environmental performance of a product or system. [S106] These declarations are based on the Life Cycle Assessment and once the assessment is complete a product or system can be certified EPD.

qa_pairs.question: How does life cycle thinking address environmental impacts across different stages of a product's life, and what role do approaches like life-cycle assessment (LCA) and life cycle management (LCM) play in this process?

# Life cycle thinking



Life cycle thinking is an approach that emphasizes the assessment and minimization of environmental impacts at all stages of a product's life. [S2] This concept seeks to avoid shifting environmental burdens from one stage of the product's life to another. [S3] It also recognizes the importance of technological innovation in tackling environmental issues. [S4] Corporations utilize this approach in the creation of environmentally friendly products. [S5] Consumers apply it in their mindful choices of products, and governments incorporate it into regulatory frameworks aimed at lessening environmental impacts. [S6] This strategy entails pinpointing crucial areas for impact reduction and enhancing consumer awareness regarding environmental concerns. [S7] ## Approaches

There are many different approaches to life cycle thinking that all involve looking at life cycle-generated impacts and ways to minimize these impacts. [S8] An important component is the avoidance of burden shifting, which ensures that improvements in one stage are not achieved at the expense of another stage. [S9] Impact measurement focuses on decreasing environmental impact and resource use throughout all stages of a process. [S10] ### Life-cycle assessment

Life-cycle assessment (LCA or life cycle analysis) is a technique used to assess potential environmental impacts of a product at different stages of its life. [S11] This technique takes a "cradle-to-grave" or a "cradle-to-cradle" approach and looks at environmental impacts that occur throughout the lifetime of a product from raw material extraction, manufacturing and processing, distribution, use, repair and maintenance, disposal, and recycling. [S12] ### Life cycle management (LCM)

Life cycle management is a business approach to managing the total life cycle of products and services. [S13] It follows the life cycle thinking that businesses, through the activities they must perform, have environmental, social, and economic impacts. [S14] LCM is used to understand and analyze the life cycle stages of products and services of a business, identify potential economic, social, or environmental risks and opportunities at each stage and create ways to act upon those opportunities and reduce potential risks. [S15] ### Life cycle costing (LCC)

Life cycle costing (or life cycle cost analysis) is the total cost analysis of a process or system. [S16] This includes costs incurred over the life of the system and is frequently used to find the most cost-effective means for providing goods and services. [S17] ### Design for the Environment

Design for the Environment Program (DfE) was created in 1992 by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and works to prevent pollution and reduce the risks pollution presents to humans and the environment. [S18] The main goals of the DfE are to promote green cleaning, recognize safer industrial and consumer products through safer product labeling, define best practices in production and manufacturing, and identify safer chemicals for these processes based on life cycle thinking. [S19] ### Product service system

Product service systems (PSS) are sets of marketable products and services that work together to fulfill a user's needs. [S20] This approach is a result of firms realizing that services in combination with products can provide higher profits and customer satisfaction than simply selling products alone. [S21] Firms that use PSS work to find ways to maximize the use of their product throughout its lifetime, using services to supplement its usage. [S22] PSS has been seen to have a smaller environmental impact than traditional business models, as the focus on services has led to a decrease in material production and consumption. [S23] This applies to life cycle thinking because it involves looking at the life-cycle cost of a product (i.e. [S24] maintenance and storage costs) for a consumer and reducing that cost by providing services with the purchased good. [S25] ### Integrated product policy (IPP)

# Life cycle thinking



Life cycle thinking is an approach that emphasizes the assessment and minimization of environmental impacts at all stages of a product's life. [S2] This concept seeks to avoid shifting environmental burdens from one stage of the product's life to another. [S3] It also recognizes the importance of technological innovation in tackling environmental issues. [S4] Corporations utilize this approach in the creation of environmentally friendly products. [S5] Consumers apply it in their mindful choices of products, and governments incorporate it into regulatory frameworks aimed at lessening environmental impacts. [S6] This strategy entails pinpointing crucial areas for impact reduction and enhancing consumer awareness regarding environmental concerns. [S7] ## Approaches

There are many different approaches to life cycle thinking that all involve looking at life cycle-generated impacts and ways to minimize these impacts. [S8] An important component is the avoidance of burden shifting, which ensures that improvements in one stage are not achieved at the expense of another stage. [S9] Impact measurement focuses on decreasing environmental impact and resource use throughout all stages of a process. [S10] ### Life-cycle assessment

Life-cycle assessment (LCA or life cycle analysis) is a technique used to assess potential environmental impacts of a product at different stages of its life. [S11] This technique takes a "cradle-to-grave" or a "cradle-to-cradle" approach and looks at environmental impacts that occur throughout the lifetime of a product from raw material extraction, manufacturing and processing, distribution, use, repair and maintenance, disposal, and recycling. [S12] ### Life cycle management (LCM)

Life cycle management is a business approach to managing the total life cycle of products and services. [S13] It follows the life cycle thinking that businesses, through the activities they must perform, have environmental, social, and economic impacts. [S14] LCM is used to understand and analyze the life cycle stages of products and services of a business, identify potential economic, social, or environmental risks and opportunities at each stage and create ways to act upon those opportunities and reduce potential risks. [S15] ### Life cycle costing (LCC)

Life cycle costing (or life cycle cost analysis) is the total cost analysis of a process or system. [S16] This includes costs incurred over the life of the system and is frequently used to find the most cost-effective means for providing goods and services. [S17] ### Design for the Environment

Design for the Environment Program (DfE) was created in 1992 by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and works to prevent pollution and reduce the risks pollution presents to humans and the environment. [S18] The main goals of the DfE are to promote green cleaning, recognize safer industrial and consumer products through safer product labeling, define best practices in production and manufacturing, and identify safer chemicals for these processes based on life cycle thinking. [S19] ### Product service system

Product service systems (PSS) are sets of marketable products and services that work together to fulfill a user's needs. [S20] This approach is a result of firms realizing that services in combination with products can provide higher profits and customer satisfaction than simply selling products alone. [S21] Firms that use PSS work to find ways to maximize the use of their product throughout its lifetime, using services to supplement its usage.
